thread.title: Poll: Donald Trump dominates GOP field in New Hampshire
thread.title_full: Poll: Donald Trump dominates GOP field in New Hampshire - POLITICO

author: Nick Gass
title: Poll: Donald Trump dominates GOP field in New Hampshire
text:
Donald Trump commands the field in New Hampshire, according to the results of a Bloomberg Politics/St. Anselm College poll of Republican voters in the state released Wednesday morning. Trump earned 24 percent compared to 17 percent for Ben Carson. In third place is former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush with 10 percent, followed by Florida Sen. Marco Rubio at 8 percent, Carly Fiorina and Ohio Gov. John Kasich at 7 percent each, New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie at 5 percent and Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul at 4 percent. Other candidates drew no more than 1 percent support, with 9 percent undecided.
The poll represents a blow to Bush, whose favorability rating in the state dropped to its lowest level in almost a year of polling despite a big ad buy from the Right to Rise super PAC supporting him. About 57 percent said they had a favorable view of the former governor, down from 59 percent in May and 61 percent last November.
Still, a plurality of 22 percent of voters said Bush is prepared to be president, tied with Trump. But the Manhattan real estate mogul is seen as the best candidate to deal with Russian President Vladimir Putin, earning 31 percent with that question, followed far behind by Bush at 13 percent.
Asked a series of questions about the perceived shortcoming of the candidates in the field, 53 percent said they were less supportive of Bush because of his advocacy of a path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants. Meanwhile, 52 percent said Cruz's push for government shutdowns would turn them off to voting for him. About 50 percent said Trump's repeated insults of opponents would deter their support, but 49 percent also said it did not bother them.
Just 18 percent said that Carson's comment that Germans could have prevented the Holocaust had they been armed bothered them, while 78 percent said it would not alter their support. Meanwhile, just 11 percent said that Rubio's relatively young age would be an issue for them, while 87 percent said it did not matter.
Purple Strategies conducted the poll from Oct. 15-18, surveying 400 likely Republican primary voters via landlines and cellphones with a margin of error of plus or minus 4.9 percentage points.
